eflm 0.1
  • Reference

Fitting Generalized Linear Models

Source: R/eglm.R
eglm.Rd

eglm is used to fit generalized linear models in an equivalent way to glm but in a reduced time depending on the design matrix (see the DESCRIPTION).

eglm(
  formula,
  data,
  family = gaussian(),
  intercept = TRUE,
  weights = NULL,
  na.action = na.omit,
  start = NULL,
  etastart = NULL,
  mustart = NULL,
  offset = NULL,
  maxit = 25,
  k = 2,
  model = TRUE,
  singularity.method = c("eigen", "Cholesky", "qr"),
  x = FALSE,
  y = TRUE,
  tol.estimation = 1e-08,
  tol.solve = .Machine$double.eps,
  tol.values = 1e-07,
  tol.vectors = 1e-07,
  ...
)

Arguments

formula

A formula for the model
data

A tibble or data.frame
family

See the function glm, but here it must be specified with brackets (e.g. quasipoisson())
intercept

Logical value to determine wheareas to included an intercept in the null model (Defaults to TRUE)
weights

An optional vector of ‘prior weights’ to be used in the fitting process. Should be NULL or a numeric vector (e.g. data$weights, defaults to NULL)
na.action

a function which indicates what should happen when the data contain NAs. The default is set by the na.action setting of options, and is na.fail if that is unset. The ‘factory-fresh’ default is na.omit. Another possible value is NULL, no action. Value na.exclude can be useful.
start

Starting values for the parameters in the linear predictor
etastart

Starting values for the linear predictor
mustart

Starting values for the vector of means
offset

This can be used to specify an a priori known component to be included in the linear predictor during fitting. This should be NULL or a numeric vector of length equal to the number of cases. One or more offset terms can be included in the formula instead or as well, and if more than one is specified their sum is used. See stats::model.offset()
maxit

See the function glm
k

The penalty per parameter to be used, the default k = 2 is the classical AIC
model

A logical value indicating whether model frame should be included as a component of the returned value (Defaults to TRUE)
singularity.method

The chosen method to detect for singularity. Defaults to "eigen" but it can also be "Cholesky" or "qr"
x

Logical value indicating whether the model matrix used in the fitting process should be returned as components of the returned value (Defaults to FALSE, see the function glm.fit)
y

Logical value indicating whether the response vector used in the fitting process should be returned as components of the returned value (Defaults to FALSE, see the function glm.fit)
tol.estimation

Tolerance to be used for the estimation (Defaults to 1e-8)
tol.solve

(Defaults to .Machine$double.eps, see the function solve)
tol.values

Tolerance to consider eigenvalues equal to zero (Defaults to 1e-7, see the function control),
tol.vectors

Tolerance to consider eigenvectors equal to zero (Defaults to 1e-7, see the function control)
...

For eglm: arguments to be used to form the default control argument if it is not supplied directly. For weights: further arguments passed to or from other methods.

Value

An object of class "eglm" that behaves the same way as the "glm" class, see the function glm.

Examples

# Generalized linear model with Gaussian link
eglm(mpg ~ wt, family = gaussian(), data = mtcars)

#> 
#> Call:  eglm(formula = mpg ~ wt, data = mtcars, family = gaussian())
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#> (Intercept)           wt  
#>      37.285       -5.344  
#> 
#> Degrees of Freedom: 31 Total (i.e. Null);  30 Residual
#> Null Deviance:	    1126 
#> Residual Deviance: 278.3 	AIC: 166
